Culture-Gene Interactions in the Acquisition and Expression of Racial Prejudice

Prejudice and discrimination are among the most prevalent and detrimental social problems across societies. Prior research has demonstrated that prejudice can be shaped by the social environment and context, such as the prevalence of stereotypes and rules about discrimination within a society. Prejudice can also be influenced by individual differences in basic psychological and emotional processes, such as an individual’s level of emotional reactivity to negative events. Behavioral genetics has suggested that individual differences in such emotional processes may be influenced by genetic variations across individuals. The purpose of this study is to examine whether genes that influence these emotional processes are associated with prejudiced attitudes, especially among people who have been exposed to many negative stereotypes about other ethnic groups from their social environment. This project may provide deeper understanding of how multiple factors, such as one’s biology, personality, and the environment, may jointly contribute to tendencies towards racial bias and prejudice, and ultimately provide valuable insight into new integrative methods for reducing prejudice and discrimination.

The current project was conducted in collaboration with Professor Ying-Yi Hong at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, and with Professors Joan Chiao and Robert Livingston at Northwestern University in the United States. These collaborators were involved in the study given their expertise and experience in studying topics related to racial bias and discrimination, and the way in which one’s culture or social environment can affect psychological and emotional processes. Singapore was an ideal location for this study given that like the United States, Singapore is a richly multicultural society made up of people of diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, which allowed the researchers to examine and compare racial attitudes and biases between two distinct multicultural societies.

The research is currently ongoing and has not yet reached completion, but preliminary findings show great promise. The findings suggest that emotional sensitivity and reactivity to general negative stimuli unrelated to social situations and people (i.e. spiders, snakes) do indeed correspond to greater levels of bias against ethnic minority groups that are associated with emotionally-negative stereotypes and evaluations. Analysis of DNA samples collected from participants still need to be completed at this time, and these analyses will be used to examine whether genes associated with emotional reactivity to negative stimuli also predict racial biases. Current and future directions for this study include collecting data from a broader sample of participants and completing DNA analyses. Furthermore, racial biases and prejudice may be influenced by a number of distinct basic psychological processes, not only those related to emotional reactivity. Future avenues of research will also involve examining how other individual differences, such as styles of forming and maintaining social bonds, and the genes associated with these processes may also underlie racial biases. Through this collaborative program of research, we seek to contribute novel insights into scientific understanding of the ways in which genes may influence complex social processes, as well as broadening society’s understanding of how social problems associated with prejudice and discrimination can be reduced.
